title: Teen chess grand master banned for wearing a headband instead of a hijab
text:
Dad jailed for suffocating his toddler daughter Teen chess grand master banned for wearing a headband instead of a hijab MARISSA PAYNE Last updated 09:51, February 22 2017 
A post-match interview with Dorsa Derakhshani at the Gibraltar Chess Festival. 
An 18-year-old woman chess grand master from Iran has been banned from her national team after wearing a simple headband in her long hair instead of a hijab while competing at the Gibraltar Chess Festival. 
Dorsa Derakhshani looked like any other teenager you might see in the British territory that borders southern Spain when she competed in the tournament last month. 
Her 15-year-old brother, Borna, has also been banned from the Iranian team after he agreed to play an Israeli opponent at the Gibraltar tournament. Dorsa Derakhshani is not allowed to compete in the chess Grand Master comp because she wont wear a hijab, sad. Kekistan should host it! pic.twitter.com/tIO5PXrvDp — Kek Wills (@kekwillsit_) February 21, 2017 
Iranian Chess Federation president Mehrdad Pahlevanzadeh announced the pair's ban on Monday. 
FROM THE ARCHIVE: 
Chess: A board game believed to have been invented in India in the sixth century. 
"Unfortunately, what shouldn't have happened has happened," Pahlevanzadeh told Iran's state-run Fars news agency. 
"Our national interests have priority over everything. 
"As a first step, these two will be denied entry to all tournaments taking place in Iran," he continued, "and, in the name of Iran, they will no longer be allowed the opportunity to be present on the national team." 
Neither sibling has commented publicly on the news. — Fabio A (@fabio_142) September 14, 2015 
HIJAB HISTORY IN SPORT 
The hijab, Iran's traditional headscarf, became a compulsory accessory for women after the 1979 revolution. 
That the two young chess masters received such a harsh punishment is not a surprise. Sports in Iran and other parts of the Middle East have long been affected by the region's strict cultural norms and precarious political stance. 
Last year, American chess master Nazi Paikidze did not to compete in the chess world championships in Iran because of the country's requirement that she don a hijab. 
"Some consider a hijab part of culture," Paikidze said at the time. 
"But, I know that a lot of Iranian women are bravely protesting this forced law daily and risking a lot by doing so. That's why I will NOT wear a hijab and support women's oppression." 
The hijab made different headlines earlier in the year, however, when US fencer Ibtihaj Muhammad became the first American to win a medal wearing the traditional headscarf. Muhammad earned a bronze in the team sabre event alongside hijab-less athletes Monica Aksamit, Dagmara Wozniak and Mariel Zagunis. 
"I have to challenge this idea that in some way we don't belong because of our race or our religion," Muhammad, who is Saudi Arabian by heritage, said last year. 
She added: "Like within any religion, Muslims have conservatives, we have liberals, and we have everything in between. To paint all Muslims with one broad stroke can be frustrating." 
- The Washington Post
